title: 110_hr6770
content: The Act may be cited as the "State and Local Economic Stimulus Act". The Congress acknowledges the vital role of State and local governments in providing essential services to Americans. The economic downturn has led to increased unemployment and budget deficits for many States and localities. In 2003, Congress provided a $20 billion fiscal relief package for States, including $10 billion for anti-recession grants to stimulate the economy and protect public services. SEC. 3. ONE-TIME REVENUE GRANT TO STATES AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS. Chapter 67 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a new section providing a one-time revenue grant of $40 billion to States and local governments for fiscal year 2009. The grant will be allotted based on population data from the 2000 census, with $10 billion each for States and local governments. The $10 billion allotted to local governments will be distributed based on population data and unemployment rates within each state. $7.5 billion will be allocated to states with tier 1 unemployment rates, based on the number of unemployed individuals since September 1, 2007. $7,500,000,000 will be allotted to states with tier 1 unemployment rates for distribution to local governments based on the number of unemployed individuals from September 1, 2007, to June 30, 2008. The government will allocate $2,500,000,000 to states with tier 2 unemployment rates based on the number of unemployed individuals from September 1, 2007, to June 30, 2008. The government will allocate $2,500,000,000 to states with tier 2 unemployment rates based on the number of unemployed individuals from September 1, 2007, to June 30, 2008, determined from the Bureau of Labor Statistics' Local Area Unemployment Statistics. The government will allocate funds to states with tier 2 unemployment rates based on the civilian labor force unemployment rate from September 2007 to June 2008. States must use the funds for essential government services and to cover costs of complying with federal mandates. The government will allocate funds to states with tier 2 unemployment rates to cover costs of complying with federal mandates. States must use the funds for approved budget expenditures and cannot increase reserves with the additional funds. The government will allocate additional Federal funds to states or local governments with tier 2 unemployment rates. These funds must be spent within 1 year and certified for approved use. Definitions for "State" and "unit of general local government" are provided. The term 'unit of general local government' includes counties, cities, townships, and tribal governing bodies with substantial governmental duties. In section 6720(c) of this title, rules apply regarding Tier 1 and Tier 2 unemployment rates for States or local governments. Tier 1 rate is 0.7 or more percentage points higher in June 2008 compared to September 2007, while Tier 2 rate is less than 0.7 percentage points higher. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 67 of title 31, United States Code. One-time revenue grant to States and local governments.
